thread.title: A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot
thread.title_full: A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot

author: JOHN MARSHALL
title: A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot
text:
Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall flies upside-down with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss as he flies near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall, in the cockpit left, flies upside-down with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall exhales as he walks away from the plane after going on an acrobatic ride with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall, right, smiles as he talks Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss, left, after an aerobatic flight near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall flies upside-down with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall rides with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss as the plane spins in an acrobatic maneuver as they fly near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall, front, flies upside-down with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss on a flight near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall, left, gets some last-minute instructions from a member of the flight crew, before getting an aerobatic ride from Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss, second from right, at the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
Associated Press sports writer John Marshall, left, gives a thumbs-up signal prior to going on an aerobatic ride with Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss, right, near the pilot's home Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Ross D. Franklin A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot 
In this April 29, 2015, photo, Members of the flight crew push the plane carrying Associated Press sports writer John Marshall, seated front, and Red Bull plane racing pilot Kirby Chambliss onto the runway before Chambliss took Marshall on an aerobatic plane ride in Eloy, Ariz. Practicing three times a day, seven days a week, Chambliss turned himself into a five-time U.S. national aerobatics champion and was one of the founding pilots in the Red Bull Air Races when the series began in 2003. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin) Posted: Wednesday, October 14, 2015 2:01 am | Updated: 2:30 am, Wed Oct 14, 2015. A discombobulating ride with an aerobatics pilot Associated Press | 
ELOY, Ariz. (AP) — Blank stares and belching were the only possibilities when it was over. Any movement, even raising my head to speak, was dangerous. 
The climbing and diving at 220 mph, slaloming the tips of cactus and mesquite trees, corkscrewing, banking at 6Gs, flying upside down and end-over-end — more on that later — barely lasted five minutes, yet seemed to have the cumulative effect of a monthlong flu.
